docs.title: Concurrency & Parallelism
docs.text:
Concurrency is about managing many tasks (dealing with them at once, by switching), creating the illusion of simultaneous progress, often on a single core.

Parallelism is about executing many tasks literally at the same time, requiring multiple processing units (cores) for true simultaneous work, speeding up computation.

docs.title: ⚙️ Multiprocessing_
docs.text:
Multiprocessing means running multiple processes at the same time.

  • Each process has its own memory
  • Each process has its own Python interpreter
  • Each process has its own GIL

✔ True parallel execution ✔ Uses multiple CPU cores

Process

A process is an independent instance of a running program managed by the operating system, with its own dedicated memory space and resources.

👉 This is distinct from a thread, which shares memory with other threads within the same process.

✔ Example

import time
from multiprocessing import Process

def calc_square(numbers):
    for n in numbers:
        time.sleep(0.5)
        print(f'Square of {n}: {n*n}')

def calc_cube(numbers):
    for n in numbers:
        time.sleep(0.5)
        print(f'Cube of {n}: {n*n*n}')

def main():
    arr = [2,3,8]
    p1 = Process(target=calc_square, args=(arr,))
    p2 = Process(target=calc_cube, args=(arr,))

    p1.start()
    p2.start()
    p1.join()
    p2.join()

    print("Done!")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

✔ Both processes(p1 & p2) run on different CPU cores.

docs.title: ProcessPoolExecutor
docs.text:
ProcessPoolExecutor is a high-level API for multiprocessing provided by the concurrent.futures module.

import time
from concurrent.futures import ProcessPoolExecutor
import os

def calc_square(n):
    time.sleep(0.2)
    print(f"Square of {n}: {n*n}")
    print(f"Process ID for square calculation: {os.getpid()}")


def main():
    arr = [2, 3, 4, 5]

    with ProcessPoolExecutor(max_workers=4) as executor:
        # map applies function to EACH element
        executor.map(calc_square, arr)

    print("Done!")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

docs.title: Why Use ProcessPoolExecutor?
docs.text:
Without it :-

  • You manually create Process
  • Handle start() and join()

With it :-

  • Cleaner code
  • Automatic process management
  • Easier to scale
ProcessPoolExecutor Methods

1️⃣ submit() – Submit One Task

What it does

  • Submits one function call
  • Runs it in a separate process
  • Returns a Future object

Syntax

future = executor.submit(fn, *args)

Example

future = executor.submit(square, 4)
result = future.result()

When to use

✔ Tasks are different ✔ Need fine control ✔ Want async behavior

2️⃣ map() – Submit Multiple Tasks

What it does

  • Applies same function to multiple inputs
  • Returns results in input order
  • Blocks until all tasks finish

Syntax

executor.map(fn, iterable)

Example

results = executor.map(square, [1, 2, 3, 4])
print(list(results))

When to use

✔ Same function, many inputs ✔ Order matters ✔ Clean code

3️⃣ shutdown() – Stop Executor

What it does

  • Stops accepting new tasks
  • Waits for running tasks to finish (default)

Syntax

executor.shutdown(wait=True)

Example

executor.shutdown()

📌 Automatically called when using with

docs.title: multiprocessing.Pool (Older Style)
docs.text:
A pool is a group of worker threads or processes that are created once and reused to execute multiple tasks.

Using Pool

from multiprocessing import Pool
import os

def square(n):
    return n * n

def main():
    with Pool(processes=4) as p:
        result = p.map(square, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

✔ Similar to ThreadPoolExecutor

docs.title: 🔁 Sharing Data Between Two Processes
docs.text:
❗ Important Rule (First)

  • Each process has its own memory space
  • Normal variables cannot be shared
x = 10   # ❌ Not shared between processes

✅ Ways to Share Data Between Processes

  1. Queue (Most common)
  2. Pipe
  3. Value
  4. Array
  5. Manager

docs.title: 1️⃣ Queue
docs.text:
👉 Best & Most used

What is it?

  • A FIFO data structure
  • Safe for multiple processes
  • Used for sending messages or data

✔ Example

from multiprocessing import Process, Queue

def sender(q):
    q.put("Hello from Process 1")

def receiver(q):
    msg = q.get()
    print("Received:", msg)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    q = Queue()

    p1 = Process(target=sender, args=(q,))
    p2 = Process(target=receiver, args=(q,))

    p1.start()
    p2.start()
    p1.join()
    p2.join()

Output

Received: Hello from Process 1
  • Safe
  • Simple
  • Most commonly used

docs.title: 2️⃣ Pipe
docs.text:
👉 Two-Way Communication

What is it?

  • A direct connection between two processes
  • Faster than Queue
  • Best for two processes only

✔ Example

from multiprocessing import Process, Pipe

def process1(conn):
    conn.send("Hello from P1")
    conn.close()

def process2(conn):
    print("Received:", conn.recv())
    conn.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    parent_conn, child_conn = Pipe()

    p1 = Process(target=process1, args=(child_conn,))
    p2 = Process(target=process2, args=(parent_conn,))

    p1.start()
    p2.start()

    p1.join()
    p2.join()
  • Faster
  • Not good for many processes

docs.title: 3️⃣ Value
docs.text:
👉 Share a Single Variable

What is it?

  • Used to share a single value
  • Stored in shared memory

✔ Example

from multiprocessing import Process, Value

def increment(val):
    val.value += 1

if __name__ == "__main__":
    num = Value('i', 0)   # 'i' = DataType(int-'i', float-'f')

    p1 = Process(target=increment, args=(num,))
    p2 = Process(target=increment, args=(num,))

    p1.start()
    p2.start()

    p1.join()
    p2.join()

    print("Final value:", num.value)

⚠ Race condition possible → use Lock if needed

docs.title: 4️⃣ Array
docs.text:
👉 Share a List of Fixed Size

What is it?

  • Shared memory array
  • Faster than Manager list

✔ Example

from multiprocessing import Process, Array

def modify(arr):
    arr[0] = 100

if __name__ == "__main__":
    arr = Array('i', [1, 2, 3])  # 'i' = DataType(int-'i', float-'f')

    p = Process(target=modify, args=(arr,))
    p.start()
    p.join()

    print(arr[:])

docs.title: 5️⃣ Manager
docs.text:
👉 Share Complex Objects (Easy but Slower)

What is it?

  • Allows sharing :-

    • list
    • dict
    • set

  • Uses a server process

✔ Example

from multiprocessing import Process, Manager

def add_item(shared_list):
    shared_list.append(10)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    with Manager() as manager:
        shared_list = manager.list()

        p1 = Process(target=add_item, args=(shared_list,))
        p2 = Process(target=add_item, args=(shared_list,))

        p1.start()
        p2.start()

        p1.join()
        p2.join()

        print(shared_list)

docs.title: 🔑 Which One Should You Use?
docs.text:
Use :-

  • Queue → general data sharing
  • Pipe → 2 processes only
  • Value / Array → shared memory
  • Manager → shared dict/list/set

docs.title: 🧵 Multithreading_
docs.text:
Multithreading means running multiple threads within the same process.

✔ Faster execution ✔ Better CPU utilization ✔ Ideal for I/O-bound tasks

thread

A thread is a smallest unit of execution inside a program.

  • A program → can have multiple threads
  • All threads share the same memory
  • Threads run concurrently (appear to run at the same time)

✔ Example

from threading import Thread
import time

def calculate_square(nums):
    for n in nums:
        time.sleep(0.5)
        print(f'Square of {n}: {n*n}')

def calculate_cube(nums):
    for n in nums:
        time.sleep(0.5)
        print(f'Cube of {n}: {n*n*n}')

def main():

    nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
    t1 = Thread(target=calculate_square, args=(nums,))
    t2 = Thread(target=calculate_cube, args=(nums,))

    t1.start()
    t2.start()
    t1.join()
    t2.join()

    print("Done!")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Since both threads (t1 and t2) run concurrently, the order of execution is not fixed.

docs.title: ThreadPoolExecutor
docs.text:
ThreadPoolExecutor makes it easier to manage multiple threads without manually creating them.

from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor
import time
import os

def calculate_square(n):
    time.sleep(0.5)
    print(f'Square of {n}: {n*n}')
    print(f'Process ID: {os.getpid()}')

def main():
    nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
    # Create a thread pool with 2 workers
    with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=2) as executor:
        # Submit two tasks to run in parallel
        executor.map(calculate_square, nums)

    print("Done!")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

👉 Important to know?

  • Thread Pool = group of reusable threads
  • max_workers=2 → only 2 threads will run at a time
  • submit() → sends a task to thread pool

  • with block :-

    • Automatically starts threads
    • Automatically waits for all threads to finish
    • Automatically closes the pool
    • 📌 No need for start() or join() manually

docs.title: 🔒 GIL (Global Interpreter Lock)
docs.text:
The Global Interpreter Lock (GIL) in Python is a mutex (lock) used in the default interpreter (CPython) that ensures only one thread can execute Python bytecode at a time, even on multi-core processors.

✔ Example to Understand GIL

Single Thread 

import time

COUNT = 50_000_000

def countdown(n):
    while n > 0:
        n -= 1

start = time.time()
countdown(COUNT)

print("Time taken:", time.time() - start)

Multithreading (Still Slow) 

import time
from threading import Thread

COUNT = 50_000_000

def countdown(n):
    while n > 0:
        n -= 1

t1 = Thread(target=countdown, args=(COUNT//2,))
t2 = Thread(target=countdown, args=(COUNT//2,))

start = time.time()
t1.start(); t2.start()
t1.join(); t2.join()

print("Time taken:", time.time() - start)

❗ Observation

⏱ Time ≈ same or slightly worse

👉 Why? Because :-

  • Only one thread holds GIL at a time
  • Threads take turns (context switching)
  • No real parallel execution

docs.title: I/O-Bound Programs
docs.text:
Programs that wait for I/O :- downloading files, reading files, database queries, API calls. Here, GIL does not slow you down because:

  • When a thread waits for I/O -> it releases the GIL.
  • Other threads can run during that time.

docs.title: Programming Fundamentals
docs.text: Programming fundamentals are the core concepts and principles that form the foundation for writing code, including variables, data types, control structures, loops, functions, and algorithms.

docs.title: 1. Conditions
docs.text:
Conditions let your program make decisions.

Syntax

if condition:
    # code
elif another_condition:
    # code
else:
    # code

✔ Example

age = 18

if age >= 18:
    print("Adult")
else:
    print("Minor")

docs.title: Short-hand If-Else (Ternary Operator)
docs.text:
You can write an entire if-else in one line.

✔ Example

x = 10
result = "Positive" if x > 0 else "Negative"
print(result)

docs.title: pass statement
docs.text:
• if statements cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have an if statement with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.

  • The pass statement is a null operation - nothing happens when it executes. It serves as a placeholder.

a = 33
b = 200

if b > a:
  pass

docs.title: Match Statement
docs.text:
• Instead of writing many if..else statements, you can use the match statement.
  • The match statement selects one of many code blocks to be executed.

Syntax

match expression:
  case x:
    code block
  case y:
    code block
  case z:
    code block

✔ Example

day = 4
match day:
  case 1:
    print("Monday")
  case 2:
    print("Tuesday")
  case 3:
    print("Wednesday")
  case 4:
    print("Thursday")
  case 5:
    print("Friday")
  case 6:
    print("Saturday")
  case 7:
    print("Sunday")

docs.title: 2. Loops
docs.text: Loops repeat a block of code multiple times.

docs.title: 1. For Loop
docs.text:
• Used when you know how many times to repeat.
for i in range(5):
    print(i)

Output:

0 1 2 3 4
  • A for loop is used for iterating over a sequence (that is either a list, a tuple, a dictionary, a set, or a string).
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  print(x)

docs.title: ✔ range, enumerate, and zip
docs.text:
range()

range() is used to generate a sequence of numbers.

for i in range(10):
    print(i)
enumerate()

enumerate() gives you both index and value when looping through a list.

for i, j in enumerate(['a', 'b', 'c']):
    print(i, j)
zip()

zip() combines 2 (or more) lists element-by-element.

for i, j in zip(['a', 'b', 'c'], ['x', 'y', 'z']):
    print(i, j)

So the loop runs like:

  • i='a', j='x'
  • i='b', j='y'
  • i='c', j='z'

Output:

    a x
    b y
    c z

docs.title: 2. while Loop
docs.text:
Runs until the condition becomes false.

count = 1
while count <= 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

Output:

1 2 3 4 5

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.
  • A function helps avoiding code repetition.
  • A function can return data as a result.

Syntax

def function_name(parameters):
    # code
    return value

✔ Example

def add(a, b):
    return a + b

print(add(3, 4))   # Output: 7

docs.title: 1. *args → many positional arguments
docs.text:
• args means arguments
  • * means collect all extra positional arguments
  • Inside the function, args becomes a tuple containing all the passed arguments

✔ Example

def add(*args):
    print(args)

add(1, 2, 3)

Output:

(1, 2, 3)

docs.title: 2. **kwargs → many keyword arguments
docs.text:
• kwargs means keyword arguments
  • ** means collect all extra named arguments
  • Inside the function, kwargs becomes a dictionary containing all the keyword arguments

✔ Example

def details(**kwargs):
    print(kwargs)

details(name="Nitesh", age=21)

Output:

{'name': 'Nitesh', 'age': 21}

docs.title: ⭐ Lambda Function (Anonymous Function)
docs.text:
• A lambda function is a small, one-line function in Python that does not need a name.
  • It is mainly used when you need a quick, temporary function.

Syntax

lambda arguments: expression

Example

square = lambda x: x * x
print(square(5))

Output

25

docs.title: ✔ Lambda with map()
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]
doubles = list(map(lambda x: x * 2, nums))
print(doubles)

Output

[2, 4, 6, 8]

docs.title: 1. List
docs.text:
A list is a collection of items that is :-

  • Ordered
  • Mutable (can be changed)
  • Allows duplicate elements
  • Can store different data types

Example

my_list = [10, 20, 30, "hello", 4.5]

Creating Lists

lst = [1, 2, 3]
lst = list([1, 2, 3])
lst = []   # empty list

Accessing List Elements

Indexing

lst[0]   # first element
lst[-1]  # last element

Slicing

lst[1:4]   # from index 1 to 3
lst[:3]    # from start to 2
lst[2:]    # from index 2 to end
lst[::-1]  # reverse list

✅ Useful List Methods

Method Description append(x) Add item at end insert(i, x) Insert at index remove(x) Remove first occurrence pop(i) Remove & return element clear() Remove all items sort() Sort list (ascending) reverse() Reverse list count(x) Count frequency

docs.title: 2. Tuple
docs.text:
A tuple is :-

  • Ordered
  • Immutable (cannot be changed)
  • Allows duplicates
  • Faster than lists
  • Used for constant / fixed data

Example

my_tuple = (1, 2, 3)

Creating Tuples

t = (1, 2, 3)
t = tuple([1, 2, 3])
t = ()              # empty tuple
t = (5,)            # single-element tuple must end with comma

Accessing Tuple Elements

Same as list:

t[0]
t[-1]
t[1:3]

✅ Tuple Methods

Method Description count(x) Counts occurrences index(x) Returns index

docs.text: Feature List Tuple Mutability Mutable Immutable Performance Slower Faster Memory Usage More Less Use Case Dynamic Data Fixed Data

docs.title: 1. map()
docs.text:
Applies a function to every item in an iterable.

Syntax

map(function, iterable)

# Returns: a map object (you must convert it to list/tuple to see results)

✔ Example

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]

result = list(map(lambda x: x*2, nums))
print(result)

Output

[2, 4, 6, 8]

# The lambda function doubles each number.

✔ map() with a normal function

def square(x):
    return x*x

result = list(map(square, [1, 2, 3]))
print(result)

Output

[1, 4, 9]

docs.title: 2. filter()
docs.text:
Filters items based on a condition (keeps only True values).

Syntax

filter(function, iterable)

# Returns: filter object (convert to list to view)

✔ Example

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

result = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, nums))
print(result)

Output

[2, 4]

# Keeps only even numbers.

✔ filter() with function

def is_positive(x):
    return x > 0

result = list(filter(is_positive, [-1, 0, 2, 3]))
print(result)

Output

[2, 3]

docs.title: 3. reduce()
docs.text:
Applies a function cumulatively to all items (reduces list to a single value).

  • reduce() is NOT built-in, it is in functools.

Syntax

from functools import reduce
reduce(function, iterable)

✔ Example: Sum of list

from functools import reduce

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]

result = reduce(lambda a, b: a + b, nums)
print(result)

Output

10

This works like:

  • Step 1: 1 + 2 = 3
  • Step 2: 3 + 3 = 6
  • Step 3: 6 + 4 = 10

✔ Another example: Find maximum

from functools import reduce

nums = [10, 5, 20, 7]

result = reduce(lambda a, b: a if a > b else b, nums)
print(result)

Output

20

docs.title: 1. Dictionary (dict)
docs.text:
• A dictionary is a collection of key–value pairs.
  • It is used when you want to store data in pairs and access it using a key instead of an index.

✔ Features :-

  • Mutable (you can change it)
  • Unordered (Python 3.7+ keeps insertion order)
  • Keys must be unique
  • Values can be duplicate
  • Keys must be immutable types (str, int, tuple, etc.)

Creating a Dictionary

my_dict = {
    "name": "Nitesh",
    "age": 25,
    "city": "Delhi"
}

Or

my_dict = dict(name="Nitesh", age=25)

Accessing Values

print(my_dict["name"])
print(my_dict.get("age"))      # safer (doesn't give error)

Adding / Updating

my_dict["age"] = 30
my_dict["country"] = "India"

Removing Items

my_dict.pop("age")        # removes key
my_dict.popitem()         # removes last inserted pair
del my_dict["city"]       # deletes key
my_dict.clear()           # empties dictionary

Important Dictionary Methods keys(), values(), items()

print(my_dict.keys())     # all keys
print(my_dict.values())   # all values
print(my_dict.items())    # (key, value) pairs

📌 Looping Through Dictionary

for key in my_dict:
    print(key, my_dict[key])

for key, value in my_dict.items():
    print(key, value)

docs.title: 2. Set (set)
docs.text:
A set is a collection of unique, unordered items.

✔ Features :-

  • No duplicates allowed
  • Unordered (order not guaranteed)
  • Mutable
  • Only immutable items can be added (e.g., numbers, strings, tuples)

Creating a Set

my_set = {1, 2, 3, 4}

Or

my_set = set([1, 2, 3])

⚠️ {} creates an empty dictionary, due to which use below syntax to create empty set

empty_set = set()

Adding & Removing Items

my_set.add(5)
my_set.remove(3)   # error if not present
my_set.discard(10) # no error if not present
my_set.pop()       # removes random element
my_set.clear()

docs.title: 1. Input
docs.text:
Input is taken as a string by default.

👉 input() always returns a string

  • No matter what the user types, Python treats it as text (string).

Example :-

name = input("Enter name: ")

If you type:

Nitesh

Then:

name = "Nitesh"   # string

🟦 Input an integer:

num = int(input("Enter number: "))

🟩 Input a float:

price = float(input("Enter price: "))

docs.title: Taking multiple inputs in one line
docs.text:
Example input: 

10 20

🟧 Use split()

a, b = input().split()

Result:

a = "10"
b = "20"

If you want them as integers:

a, b = map(int, input().split())

Now:

a = 10  # int
b = 20  # int

docs.title: 2. Output
docs.text:
Use print() function.

print("Hello World")

name = "Nitesh"
print("Hello", name)

✔ Print without new line

print("World")

docs.text:
Operators perform operations on variables/values.

  1. Arithmetic Operators 

    +  -  *  /  %  **

  2. Comparison Operators 

    ==  !=  >  <  >=  <=

  3. Logical Operators

docs.title: 2. Keywords
docs.text:
Keywords are reserved words in Python—cannot be used as variable names.

Examples :-

and, or, not
if, else, elif
for, while
break, continue
class, def, return
True, False, None

To check all keywords :-

import keyword
print(keyword.kwlist)

docs.title: 1. Variables
docs.text:
A variable is a name that stores a value in memory.

Features :-

  • No need to declare type.
  • Type is decided automatically (dynamic typing).
  • Variable names are case-sensitive.

  • Cannot start with numbers.

    x = 10
name = "John"
pi = 3.14

docs.title: 2. Data Types
docs.text:
Python has several built-in data types.

Numeric Types

  • int → whole numbers
  • float → decimal numbers
  • complex → complex numbers (e.g. 2+3j)

Sequence Types

  • str → strings
  • list → ordered, mutable
  • tuple → ordered, immutable
  • range → range of numbers

Mapping Type

  • dict → key-value pairs

Set Types

  • set, frozenset

Boolean Type

  • bool → True/False
a = 10          # int
b = 3.14        # float
c = "Hello"     # str
d = [1, 2, 3]   # list
e = (1, 2, 3)   # tuple
f = {"name": "Tom"}   # dict

docs.title: 1. What is an Abstract Base Class?
docs.text:
An Abstract Base Class (ABC) is a class that :-

  • Cannot be instantiated (you can’t create its object)
  • Is used to define a common structure (rules) for child classes
  • Forces child classes to implement certain methods

👉 Think of it as a blueprint.

docs.title: 2. Why do we need ABC?
docs.text:
Without ABC :-

  • A child class may forget to implement important methods
  • No strict enforcement of structure

With ABC :-

  • You guarantee that child classes follow a contract
  • Helps in clean design and maintainability

docs.title: 3. How to create an Abstract Base Class?
docs.text:
Python provides the abc module.

Required imports:

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

✔ Basic Syntax

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod
import math

class Shape(ABC):

    @abstractmethod
    def area(self):
        pass

class Circle(Shape):
    def __init__(self, radius):
        self.radius = radius

    def area(self):
        return math.pi * self.radius**2

class Rectangle(Shape):
    def __init__(self, width, height):
        self.width = width
        self.height = height

    def area(self):
        return self.width * self.height

# Creating instances of Circle and Rectangle
circle = Circle(5)
rectangle = Rectangle(4, 6)

# Calculating and printing areas
print("Circle Area:", circle.area())        # Output: 78.54
print("Rectangle Area:", rectangle.area())   # Output: 24
  • ABC → makes the class abstract
  • @abstractmethod → method must be implemented by child class
  • pass → placeholder

docs.title: Key Rules (Very Important)
docs.text:
Abstract class :-

  • Can have abstract + normal methods
  • Cannot create object

Child class :-

  • Must implement all abstract methods

Used mainly for :-

  • Design consistency
  • Polymorphism

docs.title: Method Decorators in Python Classes
docs.text:
In Python, decorators modify how a method behaves. Inside a class, the most common method decorators are :-

  1. @instance method (default)
  2. @classmethod
  3. @staticmethod
  4. @property

docs.title: 1️⃣ Instance Method (Default)
docs.text:
👉 What it is

  • Normal method inside a class
  • Uses self
  • Can access instance variables and other instance methods

✔ Example

class Student:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def greet(self):
        print("Hello", self.name)


s = Student("Nitesh")
s.greet()

Key points

  • self refers to the current object

  • Can access :-

    • instance variables
    • other instance methods

Remember

➡️ Most commonly used ➡️ Default method type ➡️ Needs object to call

docs.title: 2️⃣ @classmethod
docs.text:
👉 What it is

  • Method that works with the class, not object
  • Uses cls instead of self

✔ Example

class Student:
    college = "ABC College"

    @classmethod
    def get_college(cls):
        return cls.college


print(Student.get_college())

Key points

  • cls refers to the class itself

  • Can access:

    • class variables

  • Cannot directly access instance variables

Use case

✔ Factory methods ✔ When logic is related to class, not individual object

docs.title: 3️⃣ @staticmethod
docs.text:
👉 What it is

  • Normal function inside a class
  • No self, no cls

✔ Example

class Math:
    @staticmethod
    def add(a, b):
        return a + b


print(Math.add(3, 4))

Key points

  • Does not access :-

    • instance variables
    • class variables (directly)

  • Just grouped inside class for logical organization

Use case

✔ Utility/helper functions ✔ Logic related to class conceptually

docs.title: 4️⃣ @property
docs.text:
👉 What it is

  • Used to access a method like a variable
  • Makes code clean and safe

✔ Example

class Student:
    def __init__(self, marks):
        self._marks = marks

    @property
    def marks(self):
        return self._marks


s = Student(90)
print(s.marks)   # no brackets!

Why use it?

✔ Read-only variables ✔ Validation ✔ Encapsulation

🧠 Easy Memory Trick
  • self → object
  • cls → class
  • static → helper
  • property → looks like variable

docs.title: What is a Class?
docs.text:
A class is a blueprint or template used to create objects.

👉 It defines :-

  • What data an object will have (variables)
  • What actions it can perform (functions)

💡 Think of a class as a design, not a real thing.

docs.title: What is an Object?
docs.text:
An object is a real instance of a class.

👉 If class is a blueprint of a house, ✔ object is the actual house built from it.

Real-life Example

  • Class → Car
  • Objects → BMW, Audi, Tesla

Each car has :-

  • Properties → color, speed
  • Actions → drive(), brake()

docs.text:
class Student:

class Student:

docs.text:
__init__() is called automatically when an object is created.The __init__() method is used to assign values to object properties, or to perform operations that are necessary when the object is being created.

class Student:

s1 = Student("Rahul", 20)

class Person:

self.name

docs.title: Inheritance in Python
docs.text:
Inheritance is an OOP concept where one class (child / derived class) acquires the properties and methods of another class (parent / base class).

👉 It helps in :-

  • Code reuse
  • Better organization
  • Easier maintenance

✔ Simple Example

class Animal:
    def speak(self):
        print("Animal makes a sound")

class Dog(Animal):
    def bark(self):
        print("Dog barks")

d = Dog()
d.speak()   # inherited method
d.bark()    # own method

Output:

Animal makes a sound
Dog barks

docs.title: Types of Inheritance
docs.text:
1️⃣ Single Inheritance

➡ One parent → one child

2️⃣ Multilevel Inheritance

➡ Parent → Child → Grandchild

3️⃣ Multiple Inheritance

➡ One child inherits from multiple parents

4️⃣ Hierarchical Inheritance

➡ One parent → multiple children

5️⃣ Hybrid Inheritance

➡ Combination of two or more inheritance types

docs.title: __init__ in Python (Constructor)
docs.text:
• __init__ is a special method
  • It is called automatically when an object is created
  • Used to initialize (set up) object data

✔ Example

class Student:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age

s1 = Student("Nitesh", 21)
print(s1.name)  # Nitesh
print(s1.age)   # 21

👉 When Student("Nitesh", 21) is called, 👉 __init__ runs automatically.

docs.title: super() Keyword
docs.text:
super() Keyword is used to call parent class method or constructor.

✔ Example

# Parent Class: Animal
class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def info(self):
        print("Animal name:", self.name)

# Child Class: Dog
class Dog(Animal):
    def __init__(self, name, breed):
        super().__init__(name)   # Call parent constructor
        self.breed = breed

    def details(self):
        print(self.name, "is a", self.breed)

d = Dog("Buddy", "Golden Retriever")
d.info()      # Parent method
d.details()   # Child method

Output

Animal name: Buddy
Buddy is a Golden Retriever

docs.title: Welcome to Docker
docs.text: Docker is an open-source containerization platform by which you can pack your application and all its dependencies into a standardized unit called a container. Containers are light in weight which makes them portable and they are isolated from the underlying infrastructure and from each other container. You can run the docker image as a docker container in any machine where docker is installed without depending on the operating system.

docs.title: Welcome to Kubernetes
docs.text:
Kubernetes is an open source container orchestration platform that automates many of the manual processes involved in deploying, managing, and scaling containerized applications.

Kubernetes automates the configuration of your applications and maintains and tracks resource allocation. A project of the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF), Kubernetes was first introduced in 2014 and has become a widely adopted platform for organizations to run distributed applications and services at scale.

docs.title: Welcome to Linux
docs.text: Linux is a free, open-source operating system (OS) that is based on the Unix family. Unlike Windows or macOS, which are owned and controlled by a specific person, company, or organization, Linux is developed and maintained by a global community of developers. The Linux kernel, originally created by Linus Torvalds in 1991, serves as the core of the OS, managing hardware and system resources.

docs.title: Shell/Bash Scripting
docs.text: Shell scripting (or Bash scripting) is a way to automate tasks in a Unix-like operating system by writing a series of commands in a script file. These scripts are executed by a command-line interpreter, such as Bash (Bourne Again Shell), Zsh.

docs.title: 1. Using -x Option (Execution Trace)
docs.text: The -x option prints each command before execution, helping trace issues.

docs.title: Enable Debugging
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
set -x  # Enable debugging

echo "Hello, World!"
ls /nonexistent_directory  # This will cause an error
set +x  # Disable debugging

docs.title: Run the script:
docs.text: bash -x script.sh

docs.title: 2. Using -v Option (Verbose Mode)
docs.text: The -v option prints each command before execution, but without expansion.

docs.title: Enable Verbose Mode
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
set -v  # Enable verbose mode

echo "Running script..."
date
set +v  # Disable verbose mode

docs.title: Run the script:
docs.text: bash -v script.sh

docs.title: 3. Using set -e (Exit on Error)
docs.text: The set -e command forces the script to exit immediately if any command fails.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
set -e  # Exit script if any command fails

echo "Starting..."
ls /nonexistent_directory  # Script will exit here

echo "This won't execute"

docs.title: 4. Using trap for Error Handling
docs.text: trap allows running a custom command when the script encounters an error.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
trap 'echo "Error on line $LINENO"' ERR

ls /nonexistent_directory  # Error occurs here
echo "This message might not be printed."

docs.title: 5. Checking Exit Status ($?)
docs.text: Every command returns an exit status. 0 means success, any other number means failure.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Checking command status..."
ls /nonexistent_directory

if [[ $? -ne 0 ]]; then
    echo "Command failed!"
fi

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: ✅ -x – Execution tracing ✅ -v – Verbose mode ✅ set -e – Exit on error ✅ trap – Custom error handling ✅ $? – Exit status check

docs.title: Difference Between $* and $# in Bash
docs.text:
Feature $* $# Expands to All arguments as a single string Total count of arguments Behavior when quoted ("$*") Treats all arguments as one string ("arg1 arg2 arg3") N/A Example Output "arg1 arg2 arg3" 3

📌 Use $# when you need to check how many arguments were passed.

docs.title: Difference Between $* and $@ in Bash
docs.text:
Feature $* $@ Expands to All arguments as a single string when quoted ("$*") Each argument as separate strings when quoted ("$@") Behavior when unquoted Expands arguments like $1 $2 $3 ... Expands arguments like $1 $2 $3 ... Behavior when quoted ("$*") Treats all arguments as one string ("arg1 arg2 arg3") Treats each argument as separate strings ("arg1" "arg2" "arg3") Use Case Rarely used, can cause issues with argument separation Preferred for iterating over arguments while maintaining individual argument boundaries

📌 Use $@ in loops instead of $* to preserve argument separation.

docs.title: Using $*
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Using \$*"
for arg in "$*"; do
    echo "Arg: $arg"
done
Output: 
Arg: arg1 arg2 arg3

docs.title: Using $@
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Using \$@"
for arg in "$@"; do
    echo "Arg: $arg"
done
Output: 
Arg: arg1
Arg: arg2
Arg: arg3

🔹 Notice how $* treats all arguments as one, whereas $@ preserves argument separation.

docs.title: Shebang (#!)
docs.text: A shebang (#!) is the first line in a script that tells the operating system which interpreter to use to execute the script.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
#!/path/to/interpreter
- The # symbol starts a comment, but when combined with !, it signals the system to use a specific shell or interpreter. - The path after #! should point to the executable of the interpreter.

docs.title: Common Shebangs
docs.text: Shebang Interpreter #!/bin/bash Bash shell #!/bin/sh Bourne shell (generic shell) #!/usr/bin/python3 Python 3 interpreter #!/usr/bin/perl Perl interpreter

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "This script runs using Bash!"

docs.title: 1. The test Command in Bash
docs.text: The test command is used for evaluating conditions, such as checking file types, comparing values, and testing expressions.

docs.title: Usage of test Command
docs.text:
It can be used in three ways :-

  1. Using test keyword: 
    test condition
  2. Using [ ] (Square Brackets) - Equivalent to test: 
    [ condition ]
  3. Using [[ ]] (Double Brackets) - Advanced version: 
    [[ condition ]]
why we should use (Double Brackets) [[ condition ]] not (Square Brackets) [ condition ] 
#! /bin/bash

name1="lo ki"
name2="lo ki"
if [ ${name1} == ${name2} ]
then
    echo "both strings are equal"
fi

the above script gives you error like too many arguments after running.

#! /bin/bash

name1="lo ki"
name2="lo ki"
if [[ ${name1} == ${name2} ]]
then
    echo "both strings are equal"
fi

but the same code does not gives you error if you use (Double Brackets) [[ condition ]]

docs.title: Testing Numbers
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
a=10
b=20

if [[ ${a} -lt ${b} ]]; then
    echo "${a} is less than ${b}"
fi

docs.title: Numeric Comparison Operators
docs.text: Operator Description -eq Equal to -ne Not equal to -gt Greater than -lt Less than -ge Greater than or equal to -le Less than or equal to

docs.title: Testing Strings
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
str1="hello"
str2="world"

if [[ "${str1}" = "${str2}" ]]; then
    echo "Strings are equal"
else
    echo "Strings are not equal"
fi

docs.title: String Comparison Operators
docs.text: Operator Description = Strings are equal != Strings are not equal -z String is empty -n String is not empty

docs.title: Testing File Conditions
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
file="testfile.txt"

if [[ -f "${file}" ]]; then
    echo "${file} exists"
else
    echo "${file} does not exist"
fi

docs.title: File Test Operators
docs.text: Operator Description -f File exists and is a regular file -d File is a directory -e File exists -r File is readable -w File is writable -x File is executable -s File exists and is not empty

docs.title: 2. The $? Variable in Bash
docs.text: The $? variable holds the exit status of the last executed command.

docs.title: Exit Status Meaning
docs.text:
• 0 → Command executed successfully (true)
  • 1-255 → Command failed (false)

docs.title: Checking Success
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
ls /home
echo "Exit status: $?"
Output (if successful): 
Exit status: 0

docs.title: Checking Failure
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
ls /nonexistent_directory
echo "Exit status: $?"
Output (if the directory doesn’t exist): 
ls: cannot access '/nonexistent_directory': No such file or directory
Exit status: 2

docs.title: Using $? in an if Statement
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
mkdir test_directory

if [[ $? -eq 0 ]]; then
    echo "Directory created successfully"
else
    echo "Failed to create directory"
fi

docs.title: Checking Internet Connection
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
ping -c 1 google.com

if [[ $? -eq 0 ]]; then
    echo "Internet connection is working"
else
    echo "No internet connection"
fi

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• The test command (or [ ] and [[ ]]) is used for condition testing.
  • $? stores the exit status of the last command.
  • 0 means success, while non-zero values indicate failure.
  • Useful for error handling and debugging in scripts.

docs.title: Arithmetic operations
docs.text: Bash supports arithmetic operations using different methods. Below are some common ways to perform arithmetic calculations in a Bash script.

docs.title: 1. Using expr Command
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
a=10
b=5
sum=$(expr $a + $b)
echo "Sum: $sum"

docs.title: 2. Using $(( )) (Recommended)
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
a=10
b=5
sum=$((a + b))
diff=$((a - b))
mul=$((a * b))
div=$((a / b))
mod=$((a % b))

echo "Sum: $sum"
echo "Difference: $diff"
echo "Product: $mul"
echo "Quotient: $div"
echo "Modulus: $mod"

docs.title: 3. Using let Command
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
a=10
b=5
let sum=a+b
let diff=a-b
let mul=a*b
let div=a/b
let mod=a%b

echo "Sum: $sum"
echo "Difference: $diff"
echo "Product: $mul"
echo "Quotient: $div"
echo "Modulus: $mod"

docs.title: 4. Using bc for Floating Point Arithmetic
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
a=10
b=3
div=$(echo "scale=2; $a / $b" | bc)
echo "Division: $div"

If you need floating-point calculations, bc is the best choice.

docs.title: Conditional Statements
docs.text: Conditional statements in Bash allow scripts to make decisions based on conditions. They control the flow of execution depending on whether a condition evaluates to true or false.

docs.title: 1. if Statement
docs.text: The if statement executes a block of code only if the condition is true.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
if [[ condition ]]; then
    # Commands to execute if condition is true
fi

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
num=10

if [[ ${num} -gt 5 ]]; then
    echo "Number is greater than 5"
fi

docs.title: 2. if-else Statement
docs.text: The if-else statement allows executing an alternative block of code if the condition is false.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
if [[ condition ]]; then
    # Commands if condition is true
else
    # Commands if condition is false
fi

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
num=3

if [[ ${num} -gt 5 ]]; then
    echo "Number is greater than 5"
else
    echo "Number is less than or equal to 5"
fi

docs.title: 3. if-elif-else Statement
docs.text: The if-elif-else statement is used when there are multiple conditions to check.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
if [[ condition1 ]]; then
    # Commands if condition1 is true
elif [[ condition2 ]]; then
    # Commands if condition2 is true
else
    # Commands if no conditions are true
fi

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
num=0

if [[ ${num} -gt 0 ]]; then
    echo "Number is positive"
elif [[ ${num} -lt 0 ]]; then
    echo "Number is negative"
else
    echo "Number is zero"
fi

docs.title: 4. case Statement
docs.text: The case statement is used for multiple-choice conditions, similar to a switch statement in other languages.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
case variable in
    pattern1)
        # Commands if pattern1 matches
        ;;
    pattern2)
        # Commands if pattern2 matches
        ;;
    *)
        # Default case if no pattern matches
        ;;
esac

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
fruit="apple"

case ${fruit} in
    "apple")
        echo "You chose an apple"
        ;;
    "banana")
        echo "You chose a banana"
        ;;
    *)
        echo "Unknown fruit"
        ;;
esac

docs.title: 5. Ternary-Like && and || Operators
docs.text: Bash does not have a ternary operator (condition ? true_value : false_value), but you can use && (AND) and || (OR) to achieve similar results.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: [[ condition ]] && command_if_true || command_if_false

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
num=10
[[ ${num} -gt 5 ]] && echo "Greater than 5" || echo "Less than or equal to 5"

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• if, if-else, and if-elif-else allow checking conditions.
  • case is useful for multiple options.
  • && and || provide a shorthand for simple conditions.

docs.title: Functions in Bash
docs.text: Functions in Bash help in code reuse and modular programming. They allow for organizing scripts into manageable sections.

docs.title: 1. Defining and Calling a Function
docs.text:
A function is defined using the following syntax :-

function function_name() {
    # Commands
}
OR 
function_name() {
    # Commands
}

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

function greet() {
    echo "Hello, ${1}!"
}

greet "World"
greet "User"
Output: 
Hello, World!
Hello, User!

docs.title: 2. Function with Return Value
docs.text: Bash functions can return values using echo or return.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

add() {
    result=$(( ${1} + ${2} ))
    echo $result
}

sum=$(add 10 5)
echo "Sum: ${sum}"
Output: 
Sum: 15

docs.title: 3. Function with Local Variables
docs.text: Use local to declare function-specific variables.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

demo_function() {
    local name="Bash"
    echo "This is a function in ${name}"
}

demo_function

docs.title: 4. Function with Return Statement
docs.text: Functions can use return to provide an exit status (0 for success, non-zero for failure).

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

check_even() {
    if (( ${1} % 2 == 0 )); then
        return 0
    else
        return 1
    fi
}

check_even 4
if [[ $? -eq 0 ]]; then
    echo "Even number"
else
    echo "Odd number"
fi

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• Functions help organize and reuse code.
  • Parameters are passed like script arguments: ${1}, ${2}, etc.
  • Use local to limit variable scope.
  • return can be used for exit codes, while echo returns values.
  • Functions can be recursive for complex tasks.

docs.title: Loops in Bash Scripting
docs.text: Loops in Bash allow executing a block of code multiple times until a certain condition is met. They are useful for automating repetitive tasks.

docs.title: 1. for Loop
docs.text: The for loop iterates over a range, list, or command output.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
for variable in list; do
    # Commands
done

docs.title: Example 1 :- Looping Through a List
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

for fruit in apple banana cherry; do
    echo "Fruit: $fruit"
done

docs.title: Example 2 :- Looping Through a Range
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

for i in {1..5}; do
    echo "Number: ${i}"
done

docs.title: Example 3 :- C-Style for Loop
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

for ((i=1; i<=5; i++)); do
    echo "Iteration: ${i}"
done

docs.title: 2. while Loop
docs.text: A while loop runs as long as a condition remains true.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
while [ condition ]; do
    # Commands
done

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

count=1
while [[ ${count} -le 5 ]]; do
    echo "Count: ${count}"
    ((count++))
done

docs.title: 3. until Loop
docs.text: An until loop runs until a condition becomes true (opposite of while).

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
until [ condition ]; do
    # Commands
done

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

num=1
until [[ ${num} -gt 5 ]]; do
    echo "Number: ${num}"
    ((num++))
done

docs.title: 4. select Loop (For Menus)
docs.text: The select loop is used to create interactive menus.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
select variable in list; do
    # Commands
done

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

# PS3="Choose a fruit? "  # for replacing #?
echo "Choose a fruit:"
select fruit in Apple Banana Cherry; do
    case ${fruit} in
        Apple)
            echo "You chose Apple"
            break
            ;;
        Banana) 
            echo "You chose Banana"
            break
            ;;
        Cherry) 
            echo "You chose Cherry"
            break
            ;;
        *) 
            echo "Invalid option"
    esac
done

docs.title: Breaking and Continuing Loops
docs.text:
• break – Exits the loop entirely.
  • continue – Skips the current iteration and moves to the next.

docs.title: Example :- Using break
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

for i in {1..10}; do
    if [[ ${i} -eq 5 ]]; then
        break
    fi
    echo "Number: ${i}"
done

docs.title: Example :- Using continue
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

for i in {1..5}; do
    if [[ ${i} -eq 3 ]]; then
        continue
    fi
    echo "Number: ${i}"
done

docs.title: Nested Loops in Bash
docs.text: Nested loops allow looping inside another loop, enabling complex iteration patterns in Bash scripting.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
for var1 in list1; do
    for var2 in list2; do
        # Commands
    done
done

docs.title: Example :- Nested for Loops
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

for i in {1..3}; do
    for j in {A..C}; do
        echo "Outer: ${i}, Inner: ${j}"
    done
done
Output 
Outer: 1, Inner: A
Outer: 1, Inner: B
Outer: 1, Inner: C
Outer: 2, Inner: A
Outer: 2, Inner: B
Outer: 2, Inner: C
Outer: 3, Inner: A
Outer: 3, Inner: B
Outer: 3, Inner: C

docs.title: Example :- Nested while Loop
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

outer=1
while [[ ${outer} -le 3 ]]; do
    inner=1
    while [[ ${inner} -le 2 ]]; do
        echo "Outer: ${outer}, Inner: ${inner}"
        ((inner++))
    done
    ((outer++))
done

docs.title: Combining for and while Loops
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

for i in {1..2}; do
    count=1
    while [[ ${count} -le 3 ]]; do
        echo "For Loop: ${i}, While Loop: ${count}"
        ((count++))
    done
done

docs.title: 1. Read Command
docs.text: The read command is used to take input from user in Bash scripts.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Enter your name: "
read name
echo "Hello, $name!"
- Prompts the user for input. - Stores the input in the variable name.

docs.title: Reading Multiple Values
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Enter two values: "
read var1 var2
echo "You entered: $var1 and $var2"
- Reads multiple values separated by spaces.

docs.title: Silent Input (Password Entry)
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Enter password: "
read -s password
echo "Password received."
- The -s flag hides the input for secure password entry.

docs.title: Using a Prompt in Read Command
docs.text:
read -p "Enter your age: " age
echo "You entered: $age"
- The -p flag allows displaying a prompt message before input.

docs.title: Setting a Timeout for Input
docs.text:
read -t 5 -p "Enter your name within 5 seconds: " name
echo "Hello, $name!"
- The -t flag sets a timeout in seconds.

docs.title: Providing a Default Value
docs.text:
read -p "Enter your name (default: John): " name
name=${name:-John}
echo "Hello, $name!"
- Uses a default value if no input is given.

docs.title: Restricting Input to a Single Character
docs.text:
read -n 1 -p "Press any key to continue..." key
echo "You pressed: $key"
- The -n flag restricts input to a single character.

docs.title: Reading from a File
docs.text:
while read line; do
    echo "$line"
done < file.txt
- Reads each line from file.txt and prints it.

docs.title: 2. Command-Line Arguments
docs.text: Command-line arguments allow users to pass data to a Bash script when executing it.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
When running a script, arguments are passed after the script name: 

./script.sh arg1 arg2 arg3

docs.title: Accessing Command-Line Arguments
docs.text:
Bash provides special variables to access arguments:

Variable Description $0 Script name like ./script.sh $1, $2, ... Positional parameters (arguments) $# Number of arguments passed $@ All arguments as separate strings $* All arguments as a single string $$ Process ID of the script $? Exit status of the last executed command

docs.title: Example Script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Script name: ${0}"
echo "First argument: ${1}"
echo "Second argument: ${2}"
echo "Total arguments: $#"

docs.title: Run the script:
docs.text: ./script.sh Hello World

docs.title: Output:
docs.text:
Script name: ./script.sh
First argument: Hello
Second argument: World
Total arguments: 2

docs.title: Looping Through Arguments
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
echo "All arguments:"
for arg in "$@"; do
    echo "$arg"
done

docs.title: Output if run as:
docs.text:
./script.sh apple banana cherry

All arguments:
apple
banana
cherry

docs.title: Difference Between $@ and $*
docs.text:
• $@ treats arguments as separate strings.
  • $* treats all arguments as a single string.

Example: 

#!/bin/bash
echo "Using \$@"
for arg in "$@"; do
    echo "$arg"
done

echo "Using \$*"
for arg in "$*"; do
    echo "$arg"
done

docs.title: Run the script:
docs.text: ./script.sh "one two" three

docs.title: Output:
docs.text:
Using $@
one two
three

Using $*
one two three

docs.title: Variables
docs.text: A variable in Bash is a placeholder for storing data, which can be referenced and manipulated throughout a script.

docs.title: 1. User-Defined Variables
docs.text:
• Created by the user for storing values.
  • No spaces around = when assigning values.
  • Example: 
    name="Alice"
echo "Hello, $name!"

docs.title: 2. System Variables
docs.text:
• A system variable in Bash (or any Unix-like system) is a predefined environment variable that holds information about the system, user, or shell session. These variables are usually uppercase and are available globally in the shell environment.

Common System Variables

Variable Description $HOME User's home directory $USER Current logged-in username $PATH Directories searched for executables $SHELL Default shell (e.g., /bin/bash) $PWD Current working directory $OLDPWD Previous working directory $UID User ID of the current user $HOSTNAME Name of the system (host) $LANG System language setting $LOGNAME Login name of the user $TERM Type of terminal in use
  • Example: 
    echo "User: $USER"
echo "Home Directory: $HOME"

docs.title: 3. Special Variables
docs.text:
• $? - Exit status of last command.
  • $$ - Process ID of the script.
  • $# - Number of arguments passed.
  • $@ - All arguments as separate words.
  • Example: 
    echo "Script PID: $$"
echo "Number of arguments: $#"

docs.title: 4. Readonly Variables
docs.text:
• Cannot be modified after assignment.
  • Example: 
    readonly PI=3.1415
echo "Value of PI: $PI"

docs.title: 5. Local Variables
docs.text:
• Defined within a function and accessible only inside it.
  • Example: 
    my_function() {
    local local_var="I am local"
    echo "$local_var"
}
my_function

docs.title: 6. Unsetting Variables
docs.text:
• Removes a variable from memory.
  • Example: 
    name="Alice"
unset name
echo "Name: $name"  # Will print an empty value

docs.title: Linux Commands
docs.text: Linux commands are essential for controlling and managing the system through the terminal. These commands are used for tasks like file handling, process management, user administration, networking, and system monitoring.

docs.title: 1.Environment Variables
docs.text: Environment variables are key-value pairs that define system-wide or user-specific configurations. These variables influence how processes and applications behave in the shell.

docs.title: Viewing Environment Variables
docs.text:
printenv

Displays all environment variables.

docs.title: Common Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description $PATH Directories where executables are searched for commands $USER Current logged-in user $SHELL Default shell being used $PWD Current working directory

docs.title: Temporarily (valid for the session only)
docs.text:
export MY_VAR="Hello World"

Sets MY_VAR for the current session.

docs.title: Permanently (valid even after logout)
docs.text:
Add the following line to ~/.bashrc 

export MY_VAR="Hello World"

docs.title: 2. Aliases
docs.text: An alias is a shortcut for a command or a series of commands, allowing you to type less and work efficiently.

docs.title: Creating an Alias
docs.text:
alias ll="ls -lah"

Now typing ll runs ls -lah (detailed directory listing).

docs.title: Viewing Existing Aliases
docs.text:
alias

Displays all defined aliases.

docs.title: Removing an Alias
docs.text:
unalias ll

Deletes the alias ll.

docs.title: Making Aliases Permanent
docs.text:
To keep an alias after logout, add it to ~/.bashrc 

echo 'alias ll="ls -lah"' >> ~/.bashrc
Then, apply the changes: 
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: 3.$PATH in Linux
docs.text: $PATH is an environment variable that stores a list of directories where the system searches for executable files when you enter a command in the terminal. It determines which programs can be run without specifying their full path.

docs.title: Viewing the $PATH Variable
docs.text:
To see your current PATH, run: 

echo $PATH

This displays a colon-separated list of directories.

docs.title: Example Output:
docs.text:
/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin
Each directory in this list is checked in order when you type a command.

docs.title: How $PATH Works?
docs.text:
• If you type ls, the system looks in each directory listed in $PATH until it finds /bin/ls.
  • If the command is not in any of the directories, you'll see: 
    command not found

docs.title: Temporarily Adding a Directory to $PATH
docs.text:
export PATH=$PATH:/home/user/my_scripts

Adds /home/user/my_scripts to $PATH for the current session.

docs.title: Permanently Adding a Directory to $PATH
docs.text:
To make it permanent, add the line to ~/.bashrc 

echo 'export PATH=$PATH:/home/user/my_scripts' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text: ✔ $PATH stores directories where the system looks for executable files. ✔ Commands in $PATH can be run from anywhere. ✔ You can modify $PATH to include custom directories.

docs.title: 4. Cron Command in Linux
docs.text: cron is a time-based job scheduler in Linux that allows users to automate tasks at scheduled intervals. It is useful for running scripts, backups, system maintenance, and more.

docs.title: What is crontab?
docs.text: crontab (cron table) is a file that stores scheduled jobs for a user or system.

docs.title: Viewing the Current Cron Jobs
docs.text:
crontab -l

Displays the list of scheduled jobs for the current user.

docs.title: Editing the Cron Jobs
docs.text:
crontab -e

Opens the cron editor to add or modify scheduled tasks.

docs.title: Cron Job Syntax
docs.text:
A cron job follows this format: 

MIN HOUR DOM MON DOW COMMAND

Field Description MIN Minute (0 - 59) HOUR Hour (0 - 23) DOM Day of Month (1 - 31) MON Month (1 - 12) DOW Day of the Week (0 - 7, where 0 and 7 = Sunday) COMMAND The script or command to execute

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
0 2 * * * /home/user/myscript.sh

Run a Script Every Day at 2 AM

*/5 * * * * echo "Hello, World!" >> /home/user/log.txt

Run a Command Every 5 Minutes

0 10 * * 1 /home/user/weekly_report.sh

Run a Task Every Monday at 10 AM

0 0 1 * * /home/user/monthly_cleanup.sh

Run a Task on the 1st of Every Month at Midnight

crontab -r

Deletes all scheduled jobs for the current user.

docs.title: Cron Special Keywords
docs.text: Keyword Equivalent To @reboot Runs once at system startup @hourly Runs every hour (0 * * * *) @daily Runs once a day (0 0 * * *) @weekly Runs once a week (0 0 * * 0) @monthly Runs once a month (0 0 1 * *) @yearly Runs once a year (0 0 1 1 *)

docs.title: 5. History Command in Linux
docs.text: The history command in Linux allows users to view previously executed commands in the terminal. It helps in tracking past commands and re-executing them easily.

docs.title: Viewing Command History
docs.text:
history

Displays a list of previously executed commands with line numbers.

docs.title: Searching Command History
docs.text:
Ctrl + R

Starts a reverse search. Type a keyword to find a previously used command.

docs.title: Clearing Command History
docs.text:
history -c

Clears the entire history.

history -d <line_number>

Deletes a specific command from history.

docs.title: Saving and Reloading Command History
docs.text:
history -w

Saves the current session’s history to the history file.

history -r

Reloads the history from the saved history file.

docs.title: Managing Persistent History
docs.text:
Linux stores command history in a file called .bash_history. You can view it using: 

cat ~/.bash_history

To ensure that commands are saved immediately to history, use: 

export HISTCONTROL=ignoredups:erasedups  # No duplicate entries
export HISTSIZE=1000  # Set history size
export HISTFILESIZE=2000  # Set history file size
shopt -s histappend  # Append to history file, rather than overwrite
history -a  # Append new history lines to history file

docs.title: Pipe Operator
docs.text: The pipe operator (|) in Linux is used to pass the output of one command as input to another command. This allows chaining multiple commands together to perform complex operations efficiently.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
command1 | command2
command1 produces output, the output of command1 is passed as input to command2.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
sort file.txt | head -n 5

Sorts file.txt and then displays only the first 5 lines.

ls -1 | wc -l

Lists files (ls -1), then counts the lines (wc -l), giving the total number of files.

cat file.txt | grep "keyword"

Displays only the lines containing "keyword" from file.txt.

docs.title: Benefits of Using Pipes
docs.text:
✅ Avoids creating temporary files ✅ Increases efficiency by combining commands ✅ Simplifies complex tasks

💡 Tip: Use multiple pipes to chain more than two commands together!

ls -l | grep "txt" | wc -l

Finds and counts the number of .txt files in a directory.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: man [command_name]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The man command displays the manual (help documentation) for a specified Linux command. It provides detailed information, including syntax, options, examples, and descriptions.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
man ls

Shows documentation for the ls command.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: ls [options] [directory]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The ls command lists files and directories in the current or specified directory.

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description -a Show all files, including hidden ones -l Display detailed file information -h Show file sizes in human-readable format -t Sort files by modification time -r Reverse the order of output

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
ls -lh

Lists files with human-readable sizes.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: pwd

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The pwd command prints the full path of the current working directory.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
pwd

Outputs: /home/user/documents

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: cd [directory]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The cd command is used to navigate between directories.

docs.title: Common Usage
docs.text: Command Description cd /path/to/directory Moves to the specified directory cd .. Moves to the previous directory cd ~ Moves to the home directory cd / Moves to the root directory

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
cd /var/log

Changes to the /var/log directory.

cd ..

Moves to the previous directory.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: mkdir [options] directory_name

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The mkdir command creates new directories.

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description -p Create parent directories if they don’t exist

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
mkdir my_folder

Creates a directory named my_folder.

mkdir -p parent/child

Creates parent and child directories if they do not exist.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: touch [options] filename

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The touch command creates an empty file or updates the timestamp of an existing file.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
touch myfile.txt

Creates an empty file named myfile.txt.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: file [options] filename

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The file command determines the type of a file based on its content, rather than its extension.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
file myfile.txt

Outputs something like ASCII text if it's a text file.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: rm [options] [file/directory]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The rm command is used to delete files and directories.

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description -r Remove directories and their contents recursively -f Force delete files without confirmation

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
rm file.txt

Deletes file.txt.

rm -rf my_folder

Deletes my_folder and all its contents recursively and forcefully.

docs.title: 9. mv - Move or Rename Files and Directories
Syntax
docs.text: mv [source] [destination]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The mv command is used to move or rename files and directories.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
mv oldname.txt newname.txt

Renames oldname.txt to newname.txt.

mv file.txt /home/user/Documents/

Moves file.txt to the /home/user/Documents/ directory.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: cp [options] [source] [destination]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The cp command is used to copy files and directories.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
cp file.txt backup.txt

Copies file.txt to backup.txt.

cat abc.txt >> pqr.txt

Copies abc.txt to pqr.txt without replacing the content inside pqr.txt.

cp -r my_folder/ backup_folder/

Copies my_folder and its contents to backup_folder.

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• tree – Display directory structure in a tree format
  • find – Search for files and directories

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: cat [options] [file]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The cat command is used to view, create, and concatenate files.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
cat file.txt

Displays the content of file.txt.

cat file1.txt file2.txt

Displays the content of both file1.txt and file2.txt sequentially.

cat > newfile.txt
Hello, world!
CTRL + D

Creates newfile.txt and writes text into it. Press CTRL + D to save and exit.

cat >> existingfile.txt
New content here.
CTRL + D

Adds new content at the end of existingfile.txt without deleting the existing data.

cat file1.txt > file2.txt

Copies file1.txt content into file2.txt, overwriting it.

cat file1.txt >> file2.txt

Appends file1.txt content to file2.txt without overwriting.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: sort [options] [file]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The sort command sorts lines in a file in ascending or descending order.

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description -r Sort in reverse order -n Sort numerically -u Remove duplicate lines -k Sort based on a specific column

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
sort file.txt

Sorts the lines in file.txt in ascending order.

sort -r file.txt

Sorts the lines in file.txt in descending order.

sort -n numbers.txt

Sorts the numbers in numbers.txt in numerical order.

sort -u file.txt

Sorts and removes duplicate lines from file.txt.

sort -k2 file.txt

Sorts file.txt based on the second column.

docs.text: nano [filename]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The nano is a simple, user-friendly text editor used for modifying text files.

docs.title: Basic Controls
docs.text: Shortcut Function CTRL + O Save file CTRL + X Exit editor CTRL + K Cut a line CTRL + U Paste a line

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
nano myfile.txt

Opens myfile.txt with nano for editing.

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• vim – A more advanced text editor
  • echo – Prints text to the terminal or file
  • less – View file content one page at a time
  • head – Display the first few lines of a file
  • tail – Show the last few lines of a file

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The chmod command is used to change file and directory permissions in Linux. It allows users to modify read, write, and execute permissions for the owner, group, and others.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
chmod [options] mode file
- mode – Specifies the permission change (symbolic or numeric). - file – The file or directory to modify.

docs.title: Permission Types
docs.text: Permission Symbol Numeric Value Read r 4 Write w 2 Execute x 1

docs.title: 1️. Numeric Mode
docs.text:
Permissions are set using a three-digit octal number: 

chmod 755 file.txt

Sets rwxr-xr-x (Owner: read, write, execute; Group: read, execute; Others: read, execute).

docs.title: 2️. Symbolic Mode
docs.text:
Modify permissions using +, -, or = operators: 

chmod u+x file.sh

Adds execute (x) permission for the owner (u).

chmod g-w file.txt

Removes write (w) permission for the group (g).

chmod o=r file.txt

Sets read (r) permission only for others (o).

docs.title: Special Permissions
docs.text: Special Bit Symbol Description Set UID u+s Execute as the file owner Set GID g+s Execute as the group owner Sticky Bit o+t Restricts deletion in shared directories

docs.title: 3️. Applying Special Permissions
docs.text:
chmod u+s script.sh

Sets Set UID (runs as file owner).

chmod g+s shared_folder

Sets Set GID (files inherit group ownership).

chmod o+t /tmp

Enables the sticky bit (only owners can delete their files).

docs.title: 4️. Grant Full Permissions to Owner, Read/Execute to Others
docs.text: chmod 750 script.sh

docs.title: 5. Give Everyone Full Permissions
docs.text:
chmod 777 public_file

💡 Tip: Use chmod -R to change permissions recursively! 

chmod -R 755 my_folder

Sets 755 permissions for all files and directories inside my_folder.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The group command in Linux is used to manage user groups. Groups help organize users and manage permissions more efficiently. While there is no direct group command, several commands exist to create, modify, and manage groups.

docs.title: Group Management Commands
docs.text:
groupadd group_name

Creates a new group named group_name.

groupdel group_name

Removes the group group_name.

groupmod -n new_group_name old_group_name

Renames old_group_name to new_group_name.

usermod -aG group_name user_name

Adds user_name to group_name without removing them from other groups.

gpasswd -d user_name group_name

Removes user_name from group_name.

groupmems -l -g group_name

Lists all users in group_name.

groups user_name

Displays all groups that user_name is a member of.

cat /etc/group

Displays the list of all groups and their members.

💡 Tip: Use sudo before these commands for administrative tasks! 

sudo groupadd developers

Creates a developers group with administrative privileges.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The chown command in Linux is used to change the ownership of files and directories. It allows administrators or users with the necessary permissions to modify the owner and group associated with a file.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
chown [OPTIONS] [OWNER][:GROUP] FILE
- OWNER – New owner of the file. - GROUP – New group of the file (optional, prefixed with :). - FILE – Target file or directory.

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description -R Recursively change ownership of directories and files inside them -c Show output only for changed files -v Display details of the ownership change --reference=FILE Use the owner of another file as a reference

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
chown user1 file.txt

Changes the owner of file.txt to user1.

chown user1:group1 file.txt

Changes the owner to user1 and group to group1.

chown :group1 file.txt

Assigns group1 as the group owner of file.txt.

chown -R user1:group1 /home/user1

Changes ownership of /home/user1 and all files inside it.

chown --reference=existing_file new_file

Assigns new_file the same ownership as existing_file.

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• ls -l – View file permissions.
  • umask – Set default permissions for new files.

💡 Tip: Use sudo before chown if you need administrative privileges! 

sudo chown user1:group1 file.txt

Runs the command with root privileges to avoid permission errors.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The grep command is used to search for patterns within files or output. It scans each line and prints matching results, making it useful for filtering text data.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
grep [options] pattern [file]
- pattern – The text or regular expression to search for. - file – The file where the search is performed (optional).

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description -i Ignore case sensitivity -r Recursively search directories -n Show line numbers with matching lines -c Count the number of matching lines

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
grep "error" logfile.txt

Searches for the word "error" in logfile.txt and displays matching lines.

grep -i "warning" logfile.txt

Searches for "warning" in logfile.txt, ignoring case differences.

grep -v "success" logfile.txt

Shows all lines that do not contain "success".

grep "hello" *.txt

Searches for "hello" in all .txt files in the directory.

grep -c "error" logfile.txt

Counts the number of lines containing "error" in logfile.txt.

grep -r "TODO" /home/user/projects

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The find command is used to search for files and directories in a directory hierarchy based on various criteria such as name, size, type, and permissions.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
find [path] [expression] [actions]
- path – The directory where the search begins. - expression – Search criteria (e.g., name, type, size). - actions – What to do with matching files (e.g., delete, print).

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description -name Search by file name (case-sensitive) -iname Search by file name (case-insensitive) -type Search by file type (f for file, d for directory) -size Search by file size (e.g., +100M for files larger than 100MB) -exec Execute a command on found files -delete Delete matching files

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
find /home/user -name "document.txt"

Searches for document.txt inside /home/user and its subdirectories.

find /home/user -iname "document.txt"

Searches for document.txt without case sensitivity.

find /home/user -type d

Lists all directories inside /home/user.

find /var/log -size +100M

Finds all files in /var/log larger than 100MB.

find /home/user -name "*.log" -exec rm {} \;

Finds and deletes all .log files inside /home/user.

find /home/user -type f -empty -delete

Deletes all empty files inside /home/user.

💡 Tip: Use find with grep to refine searches! 

find /etc -type f | grep "config"

Finds files containing "config" in their path.
